b'Forty years ago today, on 1st October 1980, we opened our first India branch at Tulsiani Chambers Nariman Point in Mumbai. At that time the bank was called the European Asian Bank (EAB) and was renamed Deutsche Bank in 1988. From humble beginnings as a one-branch operation with less than 20 employees, Deutsche Bank has grown to become one of the largest global banks in India, with a presence in all major business centres, a balance sheet of over INR 1.2 trillion and nearly 13,000 employees. We are grateful for the trust our clients have placed in us, and the partnerships with change makers we have built across the communities we work in over the past 40 years. Take a look at some of the photographs of our first branch. How times have changed.\n\n#DeutscheBank #corporatehistory'

That\xe2\x80\x99s why I\xe2\x80\x99m clinging to it, because it\xe2\x80\x99s so rich, open to so many interpretations.\xe2\x80\x9d With their current exhibition \xe2\x80\x9cChristo and Jeanne-Claude. b'We were deeply saddened to hear the news of Christo\xe2\x80\x99s passing. The artist passed away on Sunday, at his home in New York City, two weeks before his 85th birthday. Christo Vladimirov Javacheff was born in Bulgaria in 1935, on the same day as his wife Jeanne-Claude. The two met in Paris after Christo fled from the Communist Bloc and they moved to New York together in 1964. The artist couple did not only dream the impossible, they created it. No building was too high, or lake too stormy to stop them achieving their goals. Their temporary works created all around the world are, and will remain, unforgettable for so many people.
